Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The effects of multi-species interactions on the community structure of parasites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research on infectious diseases typically focuses on single-parasite infections. However, most individuals are co-infected with multiple parasite species, and parasites interact with one another within hosts. These interactions may profoundly impact the outcome of parasite infections. For example, parasites that directly compete with one another for the same resource may inhibit each other's persistence. This project will examine the direct and indirect interactions of multiple intestinal parasites in school children in southern Vietnam. The prevalence of parasites will be quantified and interactions examined through immunological assays. This research will expand from the idea that hosts harbor only one infection at a time and will provide a better understanding of the patterns and processes shaping within-host parasite communities. Ultimately, by considering hosts infected with multiple parasite species, this research may reshape the design and implementation of global health interventions against intestinal parasites; in the short term it will aid in local public health efforts in Vietnam. The project will also advance the field of disease ecology by the study of population-level processes. It will support the training of a graduate student while increasing international colloboration.

Compared to single-parasite infections, multi-species infection interactions can profoundly impact host fitness, parasite transmission, and disease dynamics in unexpected ways. This project will investigate the effects of parasitic helminth infections on subsequent colonization by diarrheal pathogens. The first step will determine the composition of parasite communities using PCR on stool samples. The second step will use sequence the 16S rRNA gene to generate data on the taxonomy of the gut microbiota, and blood and stool samples will be analyzed for immune markers. As helminth infections occur in over 2 billion people worldwide, understanding diarrheal diseases in the context of helminth co-infections may help explain the heterogeneity in parasite burden and disease severity found amongst individual hosts and shape patterns of disease dynamics at the population level. Knowledge about such within-host parasite interactions will also have important implications for studies in disease ecology and will be important for effective management of human and animal diseases in co-infected populations. This project will foster collaborations between U.S., U.K., and Vietnamese universities and will train students in parasitological, immunological, and ecological methods. The overall study findings will be published in both English and Vietnamese and will also be conveyed to the Vietnamese community and public health system through outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to investigate how interactions between parasite species impact the incidence and severity of disease compared to hosts harboring single-parasite infections. Individuals are often co-infected by multiple parasite species, and these species may interact in ways that profoundly impact host fitness, parasite transmission, and disease dynamics in unexpected ways. My project focused on the interactions between intestinal helminths and viral and bacterial pathogens that cause diarrhea in humans. Helminths and diarrheal pathogens infect the same intestinal niche. Given that helminths induce major changes to the human immune system and gut microbiota, the presence and/or absence of helminths may lead to differences in the colonization of diarrheal pathogens in the human gut, and hence, impact host health differently.

In order to investigate the interactions between helminths and diarrheal pathogens, I conducted an intervention study in humans, whereby helminths were removed from the intestinal tract of school children via anthelmintic treatment. Stool and blood samples were collected at baseline from 570 school children in Vietnam. One week later, a single dose of 400 mg Albendazole was administered to all participants to remove any helminth infections. Three weeks post-treatment, a second stool sample was collected. Blood samples were collected to determine the effects of helminth and diarrheal infections on host immune responses. Stool samples were collected to determine the composition of parasite and pathogen communities in the intestinal tract of the enrolled participants. Stool samples were also used to analyze whether and how helminths and diarrheal pathogens interacted with the gut microbial community. Although still in the analysis phase, this data will characterize the baseline community of parasites and microbes found in the gut of school children in Vietnam. Secondly, perturbation of the gut via anthelmintic treatment will allow for detailed measures of community stability and elucidate potential mechanisms shaping interactions between helminths and diarrheal pathogens. Furthermore, results from this project will provide information on the patterns of community dynamics in the human gut, which will be of broad value in parasite community ecology.

Additionally, this intervention study allowed us to also investigate the efficacy of 400mg Albendazole, which is administered in many mass deworming programs, in helminth removal. The results indicated that this anthelmintic only has a 54% efficacy in completely removing intestinal helminths (mainly hookworms in my field site) from infected children. This is important because it demonstrates ineffective removal of helminths during these mass deworming campaigns, even though the drug did reduce worm burdens. Such underdosing can also lead to increased resistance against Albendazole in participants. These results were discussed with the Department of Health in my field site to help inform current deworming practices in Vietnam.

Lastly, this project has provided training for two undergraduates at Princeton University, who visited Vietnam to learn about disease ecology and the procedures involved in setting up and conducting a research study abroad. This project has also provided data and training for two Master's students from Vietnam for their Master’s thesis.
